author: Ross Andersen
subheading: An Oxford philosopher argues that we are not adequately accounting for technology's risks—but his solution to the problem is not for Luddites.
heading: We're Underestimating the Risk of Human Extinction

author: Scott Anderson
subheading: Greg Ousley murdered his parents at 14. So why does he think he deserves to get out of prison?

subheading: How a re-creation of its most famous battle helped erase the meaning of the Civil War.

author: Miah Arnold
subheading: The first lesson of teaching dying children is to come back the next day.

author: Chris Ballard
subheading: The three-time NBA All-Star shares a distinctive piece of NBA history with Michael Jordan. So how did he end up here, in the remotest of hoops hinterlands?
heading: If Antoine Walker Shimmies, But It’s in Boise, Is He Really Shimmying?

author: Shane Bauer
subheading: We throw thousands of men in the hole for the books they read, the company they keep, the beliefs they hold. Here's why.
heading: Solitary in Iran Nearly Broke Me. Then I Went Inside America’s Prisons.

author: Drake Bennett
subheading: Nature uses folding to manufacture some of its most intricate creations, from flowers and wings to protein and DNA. What if humans could do the same?
heading: Is Origami the Future of Tech?

author: Drake Bennett
subheading: Merging Continental and United means endless decisions, from uniforms to coffee.

author: Dan Buettner

author: Maciej Cegłowski

author: Michael Chabon
subheading: On reading—and re-reading—James Joyce's "monster."

author: Karen Russell
subheading: Last fall, one of Spain's greatest matadors took a horn to the face. It was a brutal goring, among the most horrific in the history of bullfighting. Miraculously, Juan Jose Padilla was back in the bullring—sí, fighting bulls—a mere five months later. And in the process of losing half his sight, he somehow managed to double his vision.
heading: The Blind Faith of the One-Eyed Matador

author: Adrian Chen
subheading: Unmasking Reddit’s Violentacrez, the biggest troll on the Web.

author: C.J. Chivers
subheading: Aleppo residents, battered by war, struggle to survive.
heading: Rubble and Despair of War Redefine Syria Jewel

author: Caitlyn Christensen
subheading: Cooking for the condemned.
heading: Last Meals

author: Ta-Nehisi Coates
heading: Why Do So Few Blacks Study the Civil War?

author: Pamela Colloff
subheading: On August 13, 1986, Michael Morton came home from work to discover that his wife had been brutally murdered in their bed. His nightmare had only begun.
heading: The Innocent Man, Part One

author: Ted Conover
subheading: What do you do when the cops you work for are dirtier than you are?
heading: A Snitch’s Dilemma

author: Andrew Corsello
subheading: Walken is one weird dude. But he's also so much more than that.
heading: The Many Wonders of Christopher Walken

author: Shikha Dalmia

author: David Darlington
subheading: Childhood obesity rates are soaring, youth participation in sports and other active pursuits is plummeting, and a generation is coming of age with little understanding of the joy and freedom of unsupervised play. There's a simple solution—but all across the nation our schools earn a failing grade when it comes to letting kids ride their bikes.
heading: Why Johnny Can’t Ride

author: Adam Davidson
subheading: In the past decade, the flow of goods emerging from U.S. factories has risen by about a third. Factory employment has fallen by roughly the same fraction. The story of Standard Motor Products, a 92-year-old, family-run manufacturer based in Queens, sheds light on both phenomena. It’s a story of hustle, ingenuity, competitive success, and promise for America’s economy. It also illuminates why the jobs crisis will be so difficult to solve.
heading: Making It in America

author: William Deresiewicz
subheading: Exile, ethnicity, and the search for the perfect futon.

author: Cory Doctorow
subheading: The coming war on general-purpose computing.

author: Tim Doody
subheading: For decades, the U.S. government banned medical studies of the effects of LSD. But for one longtime, elite researcher, the promise of mind-blowing revelations was just too tempting.

author: Charles Duhigg
subheading: Your shopping habits reveal even the most personal information — like when you’re going to have a baby.
heading: How Companies Learn Your Secrets

author: Joshua Foer
subheading: An amateur linguist loses control of the language he invented.

author: Stella Forstner
subheading: Growing up in the church.

subheading: The voyage of Enrique of Malacca.

author: Michael Hall
subheading: The life of a guitar.

subheading: In 2006, while in Indonesia and six months pregnant, Abigail Haworth became one of the few journalists ever to see young girls being 'circumcised'. Until now she has been unable to tell this shocking story.

heading: Not an Ike and Tina Thing

author: Anne Hull
subheading: How Tabi outran the odds against her.

author: Nate Jackson
subheading: Former Denver Bronco Nate Jackson has some words of warning for Andrew Luck and Robert Griffin III on the day of the NFL Draft.

author: Mehboob Jeelani
subheading: Hundreds of Kashmiri militants who left home as young men two decades ago have begun to return, middle-aged and disillusioned. What happens to them now?

author: Chris Jones

subheading: Especially in the case of the Waffle House terrorists, where it may be the Department of Homeland Security that's fomenting terror.

subheading: Disposable submarines, a marijuana catapult, a tunnel entrance hidden under a pool table—drug-trafficking has never been so clever, or so complicated. Inside the billion-dollar business of the Sinaloa cartel.

author: Christopher Ketcham
subheading: The antimonopolist history of the world’s most popular board game.

author: Raffi Khatchadourian
subheading: Decades after a risky Cold War experiment, a scientist lives with secrets.

author: Robert Krulwich
subheading: The legend of Ball's Pyramid—and the "tree lobster."

author: Matt Labash
subheading: Hide your kids, hide your wife, hide your husband. The end is nigh.

author: William Langewiesche
subheading: It’s the dark romance of the French Foreign Legion: haunted men from everywhere, fighting anywhere, dying for causes not their own. Legionnaires need war, certainly, and Afghanistan is winding down. But there’s always the hopeless battle against rogue gold miners in French Guiana . . .
heading: The Expendables

author: Kiese Laymon
subheading: A remembrance.
heading: How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America

author: Adrian Nicole LeBlanc
subheading: Patrice O’Neal didn’t just want to be famous, he wanted to be as good as Richard Pryor. To hear his fellow comics tell it, he was—a brutal truth-teller who spared no one, starting with those closest to him.

subheading: Dairy scientists are the Gregor Mendels of the genomics age, developing new methods for understanding the link between genes and living things, all while quadrupling the average cow's milk production since your parents were born.

author: Charles C. Mann
subheading: Does success spell doom for Homo sapiens?

author: Kathleen McAuliffe
subheading: Jaroslav Flegr is no kook. And yet, for years, he suspected his mind had been taken over by parasites that had invaded his brain. So the prolific biologist took his science-fiction hunch into the lab. What he's discovering now will startle you. Could tiny organisms carried by house cats be creeping into our brains, causing everything from car wrecks to schizophrenia? Inside the emerging science of mind-controlling parasites.
heading: How Your Cat Is Making You Crazy

author: William McGowan
subheading: The rise and incredible fall of a vicious extortion ring that preyed on prominent gay men in the 1960s.
heading: The Chickens and the Bulls

author: Jacob Mikanowski
subheading: The uncanny art of studio photography's heyday.
heading: That Face!

author: Luke Mogelson
subheading: In the dusty triangle where Afghanistan, Iran, and Pakistan meet, there is more than one war going on.
heading: The White-Hot Middle of Nowhere

author: Michael J. Mooney
subheading: In a bowling alley one night, Bill Fong came so close to perfection that it nearly killed him.

author: Adam Roberts

author: Stephen Rodrick
subheading: In recession-strapped America, Williston, North Dakota, may be some kind of paradise: a town where oil jobs are plentiful, lap dances are cheap, and desperate—possibly meth-addicted—men can change their luck. On the loose in the new Wild West.

author: Hanna Rosin
subheading: The hookup culture that has largely replaced dating on college campuses has been viewed, in many quarters, as socially corrosive and ultimately toxic to women, who seemingly have little choice but to participate. Actually, it is an engine of female progress—one being harnessed and driven by women themselves.
heading: Boys on the Side

author: David Runciman
subheading: Lance Armstrong's Regime.

author: Russ Rymer
subheading: One language dies every 14 days. By the next century nearly half of the roughly 7,000 languages spoken on Earth will likely disappear, as communities abandon native tongues in favor of English, Mandarin, or Spanish. What is lost when a language goes silent?

author: Albert Samaha
subheading: Inside a thriving open-air drug business.

author: Charles Siebert
subheading: The story of a rookie hanging on to the fragile hope of a professional football career, as told by his uncle.

author: Anne-Marie Slaughter
subheading: It’s time to stop fooling ourselves, says a woman who left a position of power: the women who have managed to be both mothers and top professionals are superhuman, rich, or self-employed. If we truly believe in equal opportunity for all women, here’s what has to change.

author: Mike Smith
subheading: North Korea’s prison camps are roundly condemned as heinous, but remain untouched. When an idealistic young reporter takes on a mission to help shut them down—bearing Hemingway and Vollmann in mind—he winds up on the doorstep of the Embassy of the People’s Democratic Republic of Korea.

author: Zadie Smith
subheading: On the many pleasures of pleasure.
heading: Joy

author: Francis Spufford
subheading: A defence of faith.

author: Bert Stratton
subheading: A member of a maligned class explains, among other things, how he keeps up the neighborhood.

author: Patrick Symmes
subheading: In Argentina, rival soccer fans don’t just hate, they kill, and the violent partisans of top clubs fuel crime syndicates that influence the sport at its highest levels. Patrick Symmes braves the bottle rockets, howling mobs, urine bombs, and drunken grannies on a wild ride through the scariest fútbol underworld on earth.

author: Jerry Thompson
subheading: The enormous fault off  the coast of the Pacific Northwest has been silent for three centuries. But after years of detective work, geologists have  discovered that it can  unleash mayhem on  an epic scale.
heading: The Giant, Underestimated Earthquake Threat to North America

author: Wright Thompson
subheading: The strange relationship between Lionel Messi and his hometown in Argentina.

author: Abigail Tucker

subheading: He was methodical, he rode the highways, and he preyed on teenage girls. Girls who'd run away. Girls no one would miss. In the summer of 1985, the author was such a girl. One night on I-95, she hitched a ride from a stranger and endured the most terrifying moments of her life.

heading: How I Hacked My Brain with Adderall: A Cautionary Tale

subheading: The far-reaching ambitions of Egypt’s rising Islamists.
heading: How a Salafi Preacher Came for My Soul

subheading: In the face of deep prejudice and persecution, the Ugandan gay rights movement has crafted a surprising victory.
